wesm commented on pull request #4005: ARROW-4952: [C++] Floating-point comparisons should consider NaNs unequal
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4005#discussion_r269250296
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/compare.cc
 ##########
 @@ -364,10 +426,15 @@ static bool IsEqualPrimitive(const PrimitiveArray& left, const PrimitiveArray& r
   }
 }
 
+// A bit confusing: ArrayEqualsVisitor inherits from RangeEqualsVisitor but
+// doesn't share the same preconditions.
+// When RangeEqualsVisitor is called, we only know the range sizes equal.
+// When ArrayEqualsVisitor is called, we know the sizes and null bitmaps are equal.
 
 Review comment:
   It's a good point. I don't know that this was necessarily deliberate, but if you are interested in seeing it fixed we can do so
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #4005: ARROW-4952: [C++] Floating-point comparisons should consider NaNs unequal
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4005#issuecomment-476784709
 
 
   Yes, we could introduce an options struct, though I'm not sure how to make it user-friendly enough. Ideally one wouldn't need to spell the options constructor explicitly, just pass "named" parameters...
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #4005: ARROW-4952: [C++] Floating-point comparisons should consider NaNs unequal
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4005#issuecomment-476790128
 
 
   Yeah, it's a trade-off. I'm thinking that this
   
   ```
   EqualsOptions options;
   options.some_option = true;
   bool result = a->Equals(*b, options);
   ```
   
   is better than
   
   ```
   bool result = a->Equals(*b, true /* default */, kDefaultEpsilon /* default */, true /* some_option */);
   ```
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #4005: ARROW-4952: [C++] Floating-point comparisons should consider NaNs unequal
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4005#issuecomment-476791996
 
 
   Being able to write one-liners would be nice.
   Perhaps something like:
   ```cpp
   bool res = a->Equals(b, EqualOptions().nans_equal(true));
   ```
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on pull request #4005: ARROW-4952: [C++] Floating-point comparisons should consider NaNs unequal
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4005#discussion_r269269406
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/compare.cc
 ##########
 @@ -364,10 +426,15 @@ static bool IsEqualPrimitive(const PrimitiveArray& left, const PrimitiveArray& r
   }
 }
 
+// A bit confusing: ArrayEqualsVisitor inherits from RangeEqualsVisitor but
+// doesn't share the same preconditions.
+// When RangeEqualsVisitor is called, we only know the range sizes equal.
+// When ArrayEqualsVisitor is called, we know the sizes and null bitmaps are equal.
 
 Review comment:
   One simple possibility is for `RangeEquals` to be implemented by slicing the inputs... It might be a tad more expensive for small inputs (allocating new vectors and shared pointers for the buffers).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description: On floating-point NaN values, the behaviour of Array::Equals and Array::ApproxEquals is currently undefined. It should probably default to something useful (and possibly be overridable using a bool parameter).
fields.summary: [C++] Equals / ApproxEquals behaviour undefined on FP NaNs
